name: TheAtlantic
text: A poem by Marie Howe, published in The Atlantic in 1994 https://t.co/46j80k0QK6

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @YasmeenSerhan: Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya wants the world to "be braver." 

For my final piece of 2020, I interviewed the self-styled leader of democratic Belarus about her country's prodemocracy movement, what's changed, and how the United States can help:

https://t.co/xTP2x5ATVI

name: TheAtlantic
text: Prestige or junk? High-brow or low-? In 2020, @megangarber writes, those distinctions mattered less than ever. https://t.co/w0EDsZ7bjc

name: TheAtlantic
text: "A college education is more essential than ever to economic stability. But across the nation, college students are struggling to cover basic needs and are unsure if they can afford tuition for the spring semester," @saragoldrickrab writes: https://t.co/FqF2oQ0NyE

name: TheAtlantic
text:
To oust Europe’s last dictator, the Belarusian opposition leader Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya told @YasmeenSerhan that her country needs the United States and the rest of the world to "be braver." 
https://t.co/n0rNDMFsjY

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @prashantrao: "Like other largely leaderless movements, Belarus’s protest has owed much of its early success to its sophisticated use of technology, its inclusivity, and its unwavering momentum in the face of both a public-health crisis and excessive government force."

https://t.co/o9jBDGwM3V

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @AdrienneLaF: "In the first week of the vaccine rollout, 614,000 Americans were vaccinated but nearly 1.5 million were diagnosed with COVID-19. Many will continue to flood our hospitals." https://t.co/bvFIOf0ONQ

name: TheAtlantic
text: 1/ This month our critic @davidlsims picked the 10 best films of 2020. We’re revisiting his list and looking back at what he wrote about some of the films when they were first released. https://t.co/K4W1yDbU9c

name: TheAtlantic
text: 2/ “Da 5 Bloods” centers on four Black Vietnam War veterans. Though it was made before the summer’s global protests against police brutality, “the sentiment feels urgent,” Sims wrote. The film also marks one of Chadwick Boseman’s final roles. https://t.co/KZuf3M5d3d

name: TheAtlantic
text: 3/ Chloé Zhao’s “Nomadland” is “a worthy exploration of the lost American dream, focusing on communities laid to waste by an economic crisis the country has already begun to forget.” The Frances McDormand–led film was a fall must-watch. https://t.co/J8lQRKgsEU

name: TheAtlantic
text: 4/ Charlie Kaufman’s “I’m Thinking of Ending Things” is more than a psychological-horror film. It’s worth rewatching: “There’s a weird thrill to getting lost inside … only so you can study every odd detail from new angles, over and over again.” https://t.co/v6HHYiUbbf

name: TheAtlantic
text: 5/ Yes, David Fincher’s “Mank”' chronicles the creation of “Citizen Kane,” but the film also “interrogates the fragile dynamic between creator and mogul that’s essential to the Hollywood business of hammering art into commerce,” Sims wrote. https://t.co/omjSKuZN6Q

name: TheAtlantic
text:
6/ Powered by career-best work from Jude Law and Carrie Coon, “The Nest” follows a couple whose relationship crumbles under the financial burden of their colossal home, proof that "wealth can rot the spirit as badly as any supernatural possession.” 
https://t.co/Zyuch5sdzZ

name: TheAtlantic
text: 7/7 Even in an unprecedented year in cinema, @davidlsims notes, “I saw many of the year’s best movies this year on my couch, alone, while in search of distraction, and they still had the power to transport, amaze, and provoke me.” See the full list here: https://t.co/K4W1yDbU9c

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @JeffreyGoldberg: "[A] stab-in-the-back narrative was buried in the minds of millions of Americans, where it burns away, as imperishable as a carbon isotope, consuming whatever is left of their trust in democratic institutions and values." 
Invaluable, from George Packer:
https://t.co/op7pJGSZcx

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @elainejgodfrey: Nursing home residents were supposed to get the vaccine by Christmas. But in Iowa and several other states there have been delays. Mary Ellen Scott, who I talked to for this story, may not get one until mid-January. https://t.co/SSOBJTAbzL

name: TheAtlantic
text:
To oust Europe’s last dictator, the Belarusian opposition leader Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya told @YasmeenSerhan that her country needs the United States and the rest of the world to "be braver." 
https://t.co/IdUJpVA02t

name: TheAtlantic
text:
1/ In 2020, we launched “Shadowland,” a series of stories on conspiracy thinking that will challenge your understanding of some of America’s most poisonous ideas.

Read on for some of our favorite stories from the project. 
https://t.co/itMvwMPyAm

name: TheAtlantic
text:
2/ Before Atlantic editor @elcush ever covered conspiracy thinking, she practiced it. “By the later part of my teens, the Illuminati was a stand-in for something I understood to be true about the distribution of power and wealth in the world,” she wrote. 
https://t.co/61DNZaqBKd

name: TheAtlantic
text:
3/ Some conspiracy theories prove harmless. Others, such as QAnon, turn out to be anything but. Our executive editor, @AdrienneLaF, explored the origins of the group in our June cover story. 
https://t.co/TrxuNF5zei

name: TheAtlantic
text:
4/ @Kait_Tiffany reported on how Monat, Arbonne, Young Living, and other multilevel-marketing companies that promise endless downstream profits have important ideological overlaps with conspiracy thinking.
https://t.co/Kz5eRl9qs0

name: TheAtlantic
text:
5/ Donald Trump may be leaving office shortly, but One America News, the network started by and for his fan base, is only growing. In May, @DevinGordonX called the network  “straight truth for Trump fans, and completely surreal for everyone else.”
https://t.co/MbX0gJhMN2

name: TheAtlantic
text: 6/6 So much of conspiracy thinking involves the belief that we are on the precipice of catastrophe—and if you believe that, preparing for it seems like the best thing to do, @AnnieLowrey wrote. https://t.co/Rako3xh4jP
